metadata.title: Explanations based on the Missing: Towards Contrastive Explanations with Pertinent Negatives
metadata.author: Amit Dhurandhar, Pin-Yu Chen, Ronny Luss, Chun-Chen Tu, Paishun Ting, Karthikeyan Shanmugam, Payel Das
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: In this paper we propose a novel method that provides contrastive explanations justifying the classification of an input by a black box classifier such as a deep neural network. Given an input we find what should be minimally and sufficiently present (viz. important object pixels in an image) to justify its classification and analogously what should be minimally and necessarily absent (viz. certain background pixels). We argue that such explanations are natural for humans and are used commonly in domains such as health care and criminology. What is minimally but critically absent is an important part of an explanation, which to the best of our knowledge, has not been explicitly identified by current explanation methods that explain predictions of neural networks. We validate our approach on three real datasets obtained from diverse domains; namely, a handwritten digits dataset MNIST, a large procurement fraud dataset and a brain activity strength dataset. In all three cases, we witness the power of our approach in generating precise explanations that are also easy for human experts to understand and evaluate.

highlights: Steve is the tall guy with long hair who does not wear glasses

Our explanation for the digit in row 1 of Figure 1 to be a 3 would be: The row 1 digit is a 3 because the cyan pixels are present and the pink pixels are absent. This second part is critical for an accurate classification and is not highlighted by any of the other state-of-the-art interpretability methods such as layerwise relevance propagation (LRP) [1] or locally interpretable model-agnostic explanations (LIME) [30], for which the respective results are shown in columns 4 and 5 of Figure 1

Low, 6) if vendor belongs to forbidden parties list, 7) if a vendor is in a high risk country, 8) if a vendor or its bank account is located in a tax haven, 9) if a vendor has a Dun & Bradstreet numbers number, 10) if a vendor and the employee bank account numbers match, 11) if a vendor only possesses a PO box with no street address
With the help of domain experts, we evaluated the performance of Contrastive Explanations Method and layerwise relevance propagation, which performed the best

Pertinent negative functional connections in all five subjects classified as autistic preferably involve the default mode network (DMN, red regions in Fig. 3A). This trend appears to be reversed in subjects classified as typical (Fig. 3C)

layerwise relevance propagation associates positively relevant functional connections from the visual network in only 40% of autistic subjects (Fig. 3D). These findings imply superior performance of Contrastive Explanations Method compared to layerwise relevance propagation in robust identification of pertinent positive information from brain functional connectome data of different populations

It’s interesting that pertinent negatives play an essential role in many domains, where explanations are important
They are more important when distinguishing a diagnosis of flu or pneumonia, rather than say a microwave from an airplane
summary: Steve is the tall guy with long hair who does not wear glasses.

This second part is critical for an accurate classification and is not highlighted by any of the other state-of-the-art interpretability methods such as layerwise relevance propagation (LRP) [1] or locally interpretable model-agnostic explanations (LIME) [30], for which the respective results are shown in columns 4 and 5 of Figure 1.
Given the original image, our pertinent positives highlight what should be present that is necessary and sufficient for the example to be classified as a 3.
This is not the case for the other methods, which essentially highlight positively or negatively relevant pixels that may not be necessary or sufficient to justify the classification.
Our method of finding pertinent positives/negatives is formulated as an optimization problem over the perturbation variable δ that is used to explain the model’s prediction results.
As seen in Algorithm 1, we use both the pertinent negative δneg and the pertinent positive δpos obtained from our optimization methods to explain the model prediction.

For LIME and LRP we picked longs to RCL, 5) if the maturity based on FI is positively relevant features as proxies for PPs. low, 6) if vendor belongs to FPL, 7) if a vendor is in a high risk country (i.e. CPI < 25), 8) if a vendor or its bank account is located in a tax haven, 9) if a vendor has a DUNs number, 10) if a vendor and the employee bank account numbers match, 11) if a vendor only possesses a PO box with no street address.
We asked for feedback on these 45 invoices in terms of whether or not the pertinent positives and pertinent negatives highlighted by each of the methods was suitable to produce the classification.
Fig. 3B shows the strong pertinent positive and pertinent negative functional connections (FC) of a classified ASD subject produced by the CEM method.
These findings imply superior performance of CEM compared to LRP in robust identification of pertinent positive information from brain functional connectome data of different populations.

We have provided a novel explanation method called CEM, which finds not only what should be minimally present in the input to justify its classification by black box classifiers such as neural networks, but finds contrastive perturbations, in particular, additions, that should be necessarily absent to justify the classification.
headline: In this paper we propose a novel method that provides contrastive explanations justifying the classification of an input by a black box classifier such as a deep neural network
